titlestmt.titleproper:
Guide to The Billie Jean King Collection
1901-2019 (bulk, 1940-2019)
MS 3147
titlestmt.author: Margaret Dalton

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2023-08-21 15:49:33 -0400.

physdesc.extent: in 42 record cartons, 2 document boxes, 21 flat boxes, 1 oversize long box, and one oversize folder

did.abstract:
Billie Jean Moffitt King is a tennis legend, holding 39 Grand Slam titles, and a champion for equality. King made advances for women's rights to equitable pay and recognition through her advocacy and participation as one of the Original 9, on the Virginia Slims Tour, with the founding of the Women's Tennis Association, the founding of the Women's Sports Foundation, co-creating womenSports magazine, and co-founding of World TeamTennis, a mixed-gender professional tennis league. King is also widely known for her 1973 victory over Bobby Riggs in the "Battle of the Sexes" tennis match.
The Billie Jean King collection includes documents, scrapbooks, publications, photographs, tennis results from Grand Slam tournaments, memorabilia, and artifacts generated and collected by Billie Jean King throughout her life and career as an athlete, an advocate for equality, and as a public figure.
did.langmaterial: The documents in the collection are in English.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: During processing the archivist devised an arrangement of ten series. In the rare instances of existing folders, original folder titles were maintained. The final order of the collection and series division is based primarily on material format.
The collection is arranged in ten series:

Series I. Early life and Moffitt family
Series II. Scrapbooks
Series III. Subject files
Series IV. Speeches
Series V. Awards and recognition
Series VI. Correspondence
Series VII. Print matter
Series VIII. Photographs
Series IX. Audiovisual and digital formats
Series X. Artifacts and memorabilia

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Billie Jean King is a tennis legend and champion for equality. Widely known for her victory over Bobby Riggs in the "Battle of the Sexes" tennis match, King made advances for women's rights to equitable pay and recognition through her participation as one of the Original 9, playing on the Virginia Slims Tour, as founder of the Women's Tennis Association, as founder of the Women's Sports Foundation, and as co-founder of World TeamTennis, a mixed-gender league. BJK also founded Billie Jean King Enterprises and Billie Jean King Leadership Initiative to address equality and inclusion issues in the workplace. King, a lesbian, has also advocated for LGBTQ rights and served on the Board of Directors of the Elton John AIDS Foundation as a founding board member and Honorary Lifetime President.

In 2009, King was awarded the Presidential Medal of Freedom, becoming the first female athlete to be honored with the nation's highest civilian honor. President Barack Obama honored King, saying "...we honor what she calls all of the off the court stuff. What she did to broaden the reach of the game, to change how women athletes and women everywhere view themselves and to give everyone, regardless of gender or sexual orientation, including my two daughters, a chance to compete both on the court and in life."

Billie Jean Moffitt was born November 22, 1943, in Long Beach, California to Mildred Rose "Betty" Jerman Moffitt and Willis "Bill" Jefferson Moffitt. BJK began playing tennis in her youth with free tennis instruction on public courts and began playing in sectional and national USLTA tournaments. From 1961-1964 BJK attended California State University, Los Angeles while competing in tennis tournaments, including Wightman Cup and Fed Cup, the annual international team competition and world cup of women's professional tennis. In the fall of 1964 BJK traveled to Australia to perfect her game working with the Australian players. In 1968 she became a contract pro.

In 1965 Billie Jean Moffitt married Cal State classmate Larry King. Throughout their marriage, BJK and Larry King collaborated on the promotion of tennis through the ownership of tournaments on the Virginia Slims pro circuit and the leadership of World TeamTennis. In 1974 BJK and Larry King co-founded and published womenSports magazine. BJK and Larry King divorced in 1987. BJK and life partner Ilana Kloss, a former World No.1 doubles player and former CEO of World TeamTennis, have been together since 1979. BJK and Kloss joined the ownership group of the Los Angeles Dodgers in 2018, the Los Angeles Sparks in 2019, and Angel City FC in 2020.

BJK holds 39 Grand Slam titles: 12 singles titles, 16 women's doubles titles, and 11 mixed doubles titles. In 1961, Billie Jean Moffitt and Karen Hantze Susman became the youngest team to win the Ladies Doubles Championships at Wimbledon. In 1966, BJK won her first major singles championship at Wimbledon and was ranked as the number one player in the world in women's tennis. She held the world number 1 ranking from 1966-1968, 1971-1972, and in 1974. Between 1961 and 1979, BJK won 20 Wimbledon titles, 13 United States titles (four singles), four French titles (one singles), and two Australian titles (one singles). In 1972, she won the U.S. Open, French Open, and Wimbledon, earning three Grand Slam titles in one year. BJK's overall Open Era titles is 168 with an overall record of Singles, Doubles, and Mixed of 782-192.

Throughout the 1970s, BJK campaigned for equal prize money to bridge the pay gap between men and women in professional tennis. In September 1970, defying the United States Lawn Tennis Association and in response to its lack of action regarding the pay disparity, BJK and eight other players accepted a $1 contract from tennis promoter Gladys Heldman in Houston as part of the "Original 9." Their vision had three goals: 1. To make sure any girl in the world if she was good enough would have a place to compete; 2. That girl and women athletes would be appreciated for their accomplishments, not just their looks; and 3. That women would be able to make a living. Their courage led to the formation of the Virginia Slims Tour. A culmination of BJK's efforts were realized in 1973 when the US Open became the first Grand Slam to offer equal prize money. The Australian Open joined in 2001, and it wouldn't be until 2007 that Wimbledon and The French Open had equal pay.

In 1973, BJK founded the Women's Tennis Association and became its first president. On September 20, 1973, BJK faced and defeated Bobby Riggs in the famed "Battle of the Sexes" match at the Houston Astrodome in front of 30,472 fans and an estimated worldwide television audience of nearly 90 million people.

In 1974, BJK founded the Women's Sports Foundation, dedicated to protecting the sports provisions of Title IX, and approached Charles Schulz, creator of the Peanuts comic strip, to join the Board of Trustees, and he became an advocate for women's sports. The WSF continues to build a future where every girl and woman has the opportunity to participate in sport and realize her power, potential, and leadership skills. King co-founded World TeamTennis and became the commissioner of WTT in 1981, making her the first woman commissioner in pro sports. In addition to the professional league, a recreational league was played throughout the country. In 2017, after forty-two years, BJK sold her majority ownership of WTT. Along with her partner Ilana Kloss, and their friend Elton John, BJK established World TeamTennis Smash Hits in 1992 as an annual all-star charity tennis match for the Elton John AIDS Foundation. BJK captained the U.S. Olympic women's tennis teams in 1996 and 2000.

Amongst many career distinctions and awards, on August 28, 2006, BJK was honored with the renaming of the National Tennis Center, home of the U.S. Open as the "USTA Billie Jean King National Tennis Center" for her contributions to tennis, sports, and society both on and off the court. In 1990 BJK was named one of "100 Most Important Americans of the 20th Century" by LIFE Magazine. In 2020 Federation Cup was renamed the Billie Jean King Cup in her honor. BJK was captain of nine Fed Cup teams for the United States. BJK was inducted into the International Tennis Hall of Fame as a player in 1987 and again, in 2021, as a part of the Original 9.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: Taking images of documents from the library collections for reference purposes by using hand-held cameras and in accordance with the library's photography guidelines is encouraged. As an alternative, patrons may request up to 20 images per day from staff.

Application to use images from this collection for publication should be made in writing to: Department of Rights and Reproductions, The New-York Historical Society, 170 Central Park West, New York, NY 10024-5194, rightsandrepro@nyhistory.org. Phone: (212) 873-3400 ext. 282.

Copyrights and other proprietary rights may subsist in individuals and entities other than the New-York Historical Society, in which case the patron is responsible for securing permission from those parties. For fuller information about rights and reproductions from N-YHS visit: https://www.nyhistory.org/about/rights-reproductions

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: This collection should be cited as The Billie Jean King Collection, MS 3147, New-York Historical Society.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Billie Jean King collection includes documents, scrapbooks, publications, photographs, memorabilia, and artifacts generated and collected by BJK throughout her life and career as an athlete, founder of Women's Tennis Association and Women's Sports Foundation, advocate for equality, and public figure.

Personal documents include early school records, family ephemera, and family photographs, as well as correspondence. Documentation of BJK's tennis career includes photographs of matches, albums of clippings assembled by BJK's family, newspaper clippings files, and publications including articles written on BJK. Publications and photographs in the collection also capture the landscape of women's tennis over time, the activities of the World TeamTennis professional and recreational league, and additional prominent athletes in the sport from the 1960s to 2000s.

The speech files provide insight into BJK's personal history, values, and mission as expressed in her own words while addressing various audiences. Honors and certificates awarded to BJK reflect her wide-ranging influence as a tennis champion, voice for women's sport, and advocate for pay equity, gender equality, and human rights.
There are a number of items throughout the collection documenting the career and recognition of BJK's life partner Ilana Kloss.

Throughout the finding aid several abbreviations are used, notably BJK for Billie Jean King, WSF for Women's Sports Foundation, WTA for the Women's Tennis Association, and WTT for the league World TeamTennis.

accruals.head: Accruals
accruals.p: The collection is open for additional material that may be donated over time by Billie Jean King.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Materials
relatedmaterial.p: Related artifacts and objects, including awards and trophies; athletic wear, including Ted Tinling designs; and sporting equipment, are held by the New-York Historical Society Museum. Inquiries about these objects can be directed to the Museum at: nyhscollections@nyhistory.org.

did.unittitle: Series I. Early life and Moffitt family

physdesc.extent: in 1 record carton and 1 flat file

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Series I contains material documenting the early life of BJK and the Moffitt family. Documents from early life include school progress reports, school assignments and notebooks, and high school yearbooks. Family documents include academic and career records for members of the Moffitt family, particularly BJK's parents and brother Randy Moffitt, a Major League Baseball pitcher. Also included is a file of postcards and correspondence sent by BJK to her family and correspondence shared amongst the family. Material in this series dates from 1933-2014.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p:
Arranged in two subseries:
Subseries I.A. Early life
Subseries I.B. Moffitt family

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Subseries I.A. includes records documenting BJK's childhood and early education. Materials include documents from Sunday School at First Church of the Brethren Church, school progress reports and report cards from Long Beach Public Schools, academic assignments and notebooks, high school yearbooks, a sorority fabric swatch, programs for BJK's high school commencement ceremony, and a copy of BJK's birth certificate. The bulk date of material is 1949-1961, with the birth certificate dated 2006 to reflect the year requested and delivered.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Subseries I.B. includes material documenting the lives and careers of the Moffitt family. Material includes academic records, certificates, event programs, postcards, and letters. Family members represented include BJK's mother and father, Mildred Rose "Betty" Jerman Moffitt and Willis "Bill" Jefferson Moffitt, a police officer and firefighter, and brother Randall "Randy" James Moffitt, a Major League Baseball pitcher. Additional family members documented include paternal grandmother Blanche G. Moffitt and niece Alysha Marie Moffitt. Material dates from 1933-2014.

arrangement.p: Arranged by Moffitt family member, followed by material generated and shared amongst multiple family members.

physdesc.extent: in 7 record cartons and 7 flat boxes

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Series II contains all scrapbooks and photo albums in the collection. Album types include scrapbooks of newspaper clippings, albums containing a combination of clippings, ephemera, and photographs, and albums of solely photographs. The albums document the personal and professional life of BJK and family, including her childhood and early career, tennis career, the evolution of women's professional tennis, including the Virginia Slims Circuit, the TeamTennis league, and various events attended by BJK. Albums date from the 1940s to 2010.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Materials
relatedmaterial.p: Additional clippings are located in Subseries VII.A Clippings. Additional photographs are located in Series VIII Photographs.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: CD is restricted from access in order to ensure the digital files are not accidentally corrupted. N-YHS will be developing procedures to properly handle digital media and this content will be opened in the future after those procedures are established and implemented.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Series III contains subject files collected and maintained by BJK in the course of her tennis career and beyond. Subjects include individuals, organizations and institutions, and general office files created by BJK. Material types include handwritten notes, event files and programs, and daily schedules. The subject files reflect BJK's wide-ranging involvement with advocacy organizations and causes in addition to her commitment to tennis and the TeamTennis league. Material dates from the 1950s to 2018.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p:
Arranged in five subseries:
Subseries III.A. General subject files
Subseries III.B. Tennis career
Subseries III.C. Elton John AIDS Foundation
Subseries III.D. Film Projects
Subseries III.E. World TeamTennis

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Subseries III.A contains general office files, files kept by BJK on individual colleagues and public figures, and files on particular organizations and institutions. General files include BJK's address books, daily calendars, and letterhead. Notable individuals with a personal subject file include Hillary Clinton, tennis player Althea Gibson, Elton John, Charles Schulz, and BJK's first tennis coach Clyde Walker. Subject files on particular organizations include event programs and notes. Notable organizations with a subject file include the BJK Leadership Initiative, founded in 2014 by BJK and Ilana Kloss, the Women's Sports Foundation, founded by BJK in 1974, and the Women's Tennis Association, formed by BJK in 1973. Material dates from the 1950s-2018.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Contains materials related to the Women's Sports Foundation, an organization started by BJK in 1974 to advance the lives of women and girls through greater access to sports and physical activity and to protect the sports provisions of Title IX. Documents include publicity material, programs for the Annual Salute to Women in Sports and The Billies events, Board of Trustees meeting agendas, handbooks, and reports, and "History of the Beginnings and Leadership of the WSF" document.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Subseries III.B contains files spanning BJK's tennis career, including tournament play, the Battle of the Sexes match against Bobby Riggs, and the evolution of women's professional tennis, including the Virginia Slims Circuit. Materials include Grand Slam tournament results, event programs, tournament brackets, and endorsement advertisements. Material dates from 1959-2000.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Series V contains certificates, awards, and documents of recognition presented to BJK throughout her life, including in the course of her tennis career and beyond. Document types include awarded certificates, related event programs, and letters of recognition. Each award file may include only the certificate itself or only related documents. Award types include official tennis ranking certificates, honorary degrees, and commemorative proclamations, reflecting BJK's varied achievements and prominence of BJK's influence.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Series VI includes letters, cards, and invitations sent to BJK by friends, colleagues, fans, and organizations. The correspondence reflects BJK's wide-ranging influence as a famed athlete, public figure, and advocate for women's equality, as well as her personal friendships and professional activities.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p:
Arranged in two subseries:
Subseries VI.A. Alphabetical correspondence
Subseries VI.B. Subject correspondence

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Subseries VI.A contains letters, cards, and invitations sent to BJK and organized individually by correspondent's last name. Contents of correspondence includes personal and professional topics. Particularly notable correspondents are identified within their respective folders or placed in a discrete folder when the amount of material justifies it. Regular correspondents of note include Bill and Hillary Clinton, Elton John, and Barack and Michelle Obama. Correspondence dates from 1952-2019.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Series VII. Print matter contains printed material collected by BJK, including newspaper clippings, magazines and journals, event programs, books, ephemera, and posters. The clippings, magazines, and journals document BJK's career, as well as tennis and women's sports more generally. The programs files document BJK's activities as an attendee of sporting and fundraising events. Many of the books in the series were signed by the author and inscribed to BJK, and their topics reflect BJK's interest and work in business and LGBTQ and women's equality. Ephemera in the series contains various single items, such as autographs, event tickets, and magazine covers featuring BJK. Posters include tennis match posters, advertisements featuring BJK, and political posters and signs. Material dates from 1901 to 2019, with the bulk dates of 1940 to 2019.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p:
Arranged in six subseries:
Subseries VII.A. Clippings
Subseries VII.B. Magazines and journals
Subseries VII.C. Programs
Subseries VII.D. Books
Subseries VII.E. Ephemera
Subseries VII.F. Posters

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Subseries VII.A contains newspaper and magazine clippings from local, national, and international papers with articles spanning 1943-2019. Topics of articles include BJK's early tennis career, various tournaments, TeamTennis, World TeamTennis, the Battle of the Sexes match, Virginia Slims Circuit, and BJK's efforts toward gender equality, as well as various interviews. Publications include the Independent Press Telegram, Los Angeles Times, New York Times, San Francisco Chronicle, and USA Today.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Files are arranged in chronological order. Articles clipped without visible publication dates are grouped together by decade, their assumed date determined by context and topical matter. Clipped articles that include dates are arranged in a folder for each year, with multiple folders when the amount of material dictates.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Materials
relatedmaterial.p: Additional clippings in the collection are located in Series II scrapbooks.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Contains programs from the following events: BJK and friends Honoring Joe Shapiro 2003, 2006, and 2007; Wimbledon Lawn Tennis Championships 2005; and New England Patriots vs. Lions December 3, 2006; Elton John at Madison Square Garden 2007 March 25; 2008 So the World May Hear Awards Gala (program inscribed to BJK by Garth Brooks); presentation of the Presidential Medal of Freedom 2009 August 23; US Open 2010; USTA Icon Awards 2012; BNP Paribas WTA Finals Singapore 2014; 2016 Ellis Island Family Heritage Awards; and USTA BJK Girls' 16s and 18s National Championships 2018.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Subseries VII.D includes books collected by BJK. Books may include an inscription to BJK from the author or an accompanying letter, which has been kept with the book if present. Topics of books include business, fitness, LGBTQ equality, sports, and women's equality. Notable books with inscriptions to BJK include Hillary Rodham and Chelsea Clinton's book, Gutsy Women. Additional notable books include the Virginia Slims Circuit media guide for the 1977 season and Benjamin Snyder's The History of World TeamTennis. Books date from 1943-2019.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Series VIII includes photographs, negatives, and slides from throughout BJK's life and career. Subjects of photos include BJK's childhood and family, youth tennis matches, professional tennis matches and events, TeamTennis and World TeamTennis events, notable people in BJK's life, and various public appearances, events, and fundraisers attended by BJK. Notable photo groups include BJK's childhood and family photos, various Wimbledon matches, TeamTennis league photos and slides, and BJK receiving the Presidential Medal of Freedom from President Barack Obama. Materials date from 1935 to 2019.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p:
Arranged in six subseries:
Subseries VIII.A. Childhood and family
Subseries VIII.B. Career
Subseries VIII.C. TeamTennis
Subseries VIII.D. Events
Subseries VIII.E. People
Subseries VIII.F. Slides

relatedmaterial.head: Related Materials
relatedmaterial.p: Additional photographs are located in Series II. Albums. Additional photographs selected by the curator and conservators to remain framed are located in Series X. Artifacts and memorabilia.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Subseries VIII.A contains photographs of BJK during her childhood and adolescence, photographs of her immediate family throughout their lives, and photographs of additional relatives. BJK's baby photos include formal portraits and family candids. Childhood photographs include BJK with parents and brother Randy and with classmates. A group of photographs originally in frames have been removed for conservation purposes and are described accordingly. Photos date from 1935 to 2010.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Photographs are grouped by family members, starting with BJK's baby and childhood photos, followed by photographs of her parents and brother, and finally Moffitt and Jerman family relatives.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Materials
relatedmaterial.p: Additional family photographs selected by the curator and conservators to remain framed are located in Series X. Artifacts and memorabilia.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Subseries VIII.B contains photographs taken throughout BJK's career as a tennis player, tennis coach, and broadcaster. The majority of photos are tennis match shots, including court play and BJK with awards. Notable files include a group of Wimbledon photos and photos from the Battle of the Sexes match against Bobby Riggs. Photos date from 1955-2005.

Subjects of photos include team rosters, match shots, community recreation league events, and the annual WTT Smash Hits benefit. A portion of this group of photos was originally organized in binders, and this arrangement has been maintained with a note in the folder title indicating so. Photos date from 1974 to 2006.

arrangement.p: Files are arranged in chronological order.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Subseries VIII.D includes photographs from various events attended by BJK, including fundraising events, sporting events, awards presentations, and television appearances. Notable events include BJK's induction into the International Tennis Hall of Fame, induction into the National Women's Hall of Fame, and renaming ceremony for the USTA BJK National Tennis Center. Photos date from 1960 to 2020.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Photographs are arranged chronologically, with general event folders containing events with one or a few photos followed by files for individual events.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Contains event photo files grouped in chronological order by proximate dating. Most photos do not have a date specified. Many events have a single photo. Event types include social gatherings, tennis matches, reunions, fundraising events, and award presentations.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Subseries VIII.E includes photograph files of particular people or groups of people, including individual shots, the identified person with BJK, and event photos of particular people and groups of people. Notable individuals include Hillary Clinton, Elton John, BJK's life partner Ilana Kloss, Barack Obama, and the Original 9. The subseries also includes a file of photos autographed and given to BJK by the subject. Photos date from 1960 to 2017.

Series IX. (RESTRICTED) Audiovisual and digital formats

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Series IX includes audiovisual and digital media collected by BJK. Formats of material include audiocassettes, videocassettes, a betacam tape, mini-DVs, VHS tapes, CDs, DVDs, and a USB flash drive. Content of media includes audio recordings of TeamTennis stakeholder meetings and ads, audio and video footage of various events and BJK interviews, commercially-released DVD films, and CDs gifted to BJK by Elton John.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p:
Arranged in four subseries:
Subseries IX.A. Audiocassettes
Subseries IX.B. Videocassettes
Subseries IX.C. Optical disks [CDs and DVDs]
Subseries IX.D. USB flash drives

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: This series is currently restricted from use. The videotapes and audiotapes are restricted because of their fragility and because N-YHS has no equipment on which to play them. The digital media is restricted from access in order to ensure that the digital files are not accidentally corrupted. N-YHS will be developing procedures to properly handle digital media and this content will be opened in the future after those procedures are established and implemented. Please contact the curator of manuscripts at manuscripts@nyhistory.org for further information.
